newsitem.title: SPAIN: Spain to boost growth with liberalisation measures.
newsitem.headline: Spain to boost growth with liberalisation measures.

text.p: Spain reaffirmed on Wednesday its plans to boost economic growth through liberalisation measures and the reduction of the public deficit.

Economy Minister Rodrigo Rato told parliament that the main target of a recently-approved three-year stability plan was to see economic growth at a higher rate than inflation, as has been the case in recent months.

"To have the economy growing above prices we will continue to follow the same economic policy which made that possible... reducing the public deficit through a new model of expenditures and (economic) reforms," Rato said.
The 1997-2000 plan forecasts average growth at 3.2 percent, while the private consumption deflator is expected to stand at around 2.3 percent.
Although the reduction of public spending should not affect private citizens, Rato reiterated that the country needs to keep health expenditure under control.
But he also explained lower expenditures are expected to stem from a reduction in public consumption and from lower financial expenditures.
Interest payments are expected to fall to around 1.1 percent of gross domestic product in 2000, with a reduction of an average 0.5 percent each year.
